awd_titl_txt: Troposphere-Ionosphere Coupling via Atmospheric Gravity Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
In our layered atmosphere, gravity (or internal) waves are quasi-periodic disturbances most familiar as the wave-like cloud patterns, such as observed in the lee of mountain ranges.  This project seeks to experimentally investigate the role of the atmospheric gravity waves in ionosphere-troposphere coupling. In particular, the dynamics of plasma density irregularities in the ionospheric F region, and the connection of  these irregularities with atmospheric gravity waves will be investigated. The investigation is to take place in Antarctica as: 1) Large numbers of gravity waves may be observed there, and 2) The electromagnetic background there is quiet, important for detection of radio signals to be observed in this study. 

To detect the density irregularities a HF receiver and transmitter will be placed at two different locations in Antarctica, probing the ionosphere along the passage between these two points. Numerical modelling will be used to describe parameters of the troposphere below the ionospheric path of the HF signal. The HF signal will give information about density irregularities, and the numerical model will give information about gravity waves in the troposphere. By comparing information of numerical model and from HF observations the investigators will be able to make conclusions about simultaneous occurrences of irregularities in the ionospheric plasma and gravity waves.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was investigation of the waves in the Earth?s atmosphere. The two types of such waves, Atmospheric Gravity Waves (AGWs) and Travelling Ionospheric Disturbances (TIDs) are responsible for the interaction between neutral and charged particles in the atmosphere. The Antarctic Peninsula region is a ?hot spot? of atmospheric wave activity and offers an excellent opportunity for such research.

To investigate the wave interaction process, both experimental and theoretical studies have been conducted. For the experimental investigation, a dedicated ground based low-power digital radar system was developed and installed in Antarctica with the purpose of detecting and tracking TID waves. Signals from GPS satellites received on the ground at both stations were also used to identify the presence and measure parameters of TIDs.

These observations were conducted primarily at the Antarctic Palmer station (U.S.) in collaboration with the researchers from nearby Vernadsky station (Ukraine) which helped promoting international collaboration in science. Using several years of collected data it was possible to establish conditions of the atmosphere when TID waves are observed most frequently. It has been shown that AGWs most efficiently produce TIDs during the daytime period, when the atmosphere is lit by the sunlight which creates sufficient number of charged particles. The presence of the preferred direction of propagation of the atmospheric waves has been established and it was shown that it is opposite to the direction of the main flow of the neutral particles. It was also found that the main characteristics of TID waves, such as amplitude, periods and propagation direction are directly related to the amount of the charged particles present in the atmosphere.

Theoretical modeling of AGW wave propagation process was performed by numerically solving the appropriate set of fluid dynamics differential equations using supercomputers. The waves originating at the ground level due to the interaction of the wind with the mountain ranges (the Andes and Antarctic Range) have been modelled. A high resolution modelling of the waves propagating upward to the heights of 300 km was performed, making it possible to track the changes in the wave amplitude, direction and period.

The results obtained in this project have significantly deepened our understanding of the physics of the atmospheric waves which are observed in high latitude regions.
